column2: known until 1537 as Bishop's Lynn and locally as Lynn
column3: is a seaport and market town in Norfolk
column4: England

column1: The etymology of King's Lynn is uncertain. The name Lynn may signify a body of water near the town – the Welsh word llyn
column2: means a lake; but the name is plausibly of Anglo-Saxon origin
column3: from lean meaning a tenure in fee or farm. As the 1085 Domesday Book mentions saltings at Lena (Lynn)
column4: an area of partitioned pools or small lakes may have existed there at the time. The presence of salt
column5: which was relatively rare and expensive in the early Medieval period
column6: may have added to the interest of Herbert de Losinga and other prominent Normans in the modest parish.

column1: The town was named Len Episcopi (Bishop's Lynn) while under the temporal and spiritual jurisdiction of the Bishop of Norwich; but in the reign of Henry VIII it was surrendered to the crown and took the name of Lenne Regis or King's Lynn. Domesday records it as Lun and Lenn
column2: and ascribes it to the Bishop of Elmham and the Archbishop of Canterbury.The town is generally known locally as Lynn. The city of Lynn
column3: Massachusetts
column4: north of Boston
column5: was named in 1637 in honour of its first official minister of religion
column6: Samuel Whiting
column7: who arrived there from Lynn

column1: Lynn originated on a constricted site south of where the River Great Ouse now discharges into the Wash. Development began in the early 10th century
column2: but the place was not recorded until the early 11th century. Until the early 13th century
column3: the Great Ouse emptied via the Wellstream at Wisbech. After its redirection
column4: Lynn and its port gained significance and prosperity.In 1101
column5: Bishop Herbert de Losinga of Thetford began to build the first medieval town between the rivers Purfleet to the north and Mill Fleet to the south. He commissioned St Margaret's Church and authorised a market to be held on Saturday. Trade built up along the waterways that stretched inland; the town expanded between the two rivers.

column1: Lynn's 12th-century Jewish community was exterminated during the widespread massacres of 1189.

column2: Lynn ranked as England's most important port. It was considered as vital to England in the Middle Ages as Liverpool was during the Industrial Revolution. Sea trade with Europe was dominated by the Hanseatic League of ports; the transatlantic trade and the rise of England's western ports did not begin until the 17th century. The Trinity Guildhall was rebuilt in 1421 after a fire. Walls entered by the South Gate and East Gate were erected to protect the town. It retains two former Hanseatic League warehouses: Hanse House of 1475 and Marriott's Warehouse
column3: in use between the 15th and 17th centuries. These are the only remaining buildings of the Hanseatic League in England.

column1: In the first decade of the 16th century
column2: Thoresby College was built in Lynn by Thomas Thoresby to house priests of the Guild of The Holy Trinity. It had been incorporated in 1453 under a petition of its alderman
column3: chaplain
column4: four brethren and four sisters. These were licensed to found a chantry of chaplains for the altar of Holy Trinity in Wisbech; lands were granted in mortmain. Lynn acquired a mayor and corporation in 1524. In 1537 the king took over the town from the bishop. In the same century the town's two annual fairs were reduced to one. In 1534 a grammar school was founded; four years later Henry VIII closed the Benedictine priory and the three friaries.

column1: A piped water supply was created in the 16th century
column2: although many could not afford to be connected: elm pipes carried water under the streets. King's Lynn suffered from outbreaks of plague
column3: notably in 1516
column6: 1636 and finally in 1665. Fire was another hazard – in 1572 thatched roofs were banned to reduce the risk. In the English Civil War
column7: King's Lynn supported Parliament
column8: but in August 1643 it was in Royalist hands. It changed sides again after Parliament sent an army and the town was besieged for three weeks.

column1: A heart carved on the wall of the Tuesday Market Place marks the burning of an alleged witch
column2: Margaret Read
column3: in 1590. It is said that as she was burning her heart burst from her body and struck the wall.

column2: the architect Henry Bell
column3: once the town's mayor
column4: designed the Custom House. He also designed the Duke's Head Inn
column5: the North Runcton Church
column6: and Stanhoe Hall
column7: having gained inspiration while travelling in Europe as a young man.In the 16th and 17th centuries
column8: the town's main export was grain. Lynn was no longer a major international port
column9: but iron and timber were imported. King's Lynn suffered from the discovery of the Americas
column10: which benefited ports on the west coast of England. It was also affected by the growth of London.

column2: imports of wine from Spain
column3: Portugal and France boomed
column4: and there was still much coastal trade. It was cheaper to transport goods by water than by road at the time. Large amounts of coal arrived from the north-east of England.

column1: The Fens began to be drained in the mid–17th century and the land turned to farming
column2: allowing vast amounts of produce to be sent to London's growing market. Meanwhile
column3: King's Lynn was still an important fishing port. Greenland Fishery House in Bridge Street was built in 1605. By the late 17th century shipbuilding and glass-making had developed.

column2: Daniel Defoe called the town "beautiful
column3: well built and well situated". Shipbuilding thrived
column4: as did associated industries such as sail-making and rope-making. Glass-making prospered; brewing was another important industry. The first bank in King's Lynn opened in 1784.

column1: A fearsome example of penal brutality occurred on 28 September 1708
column2: when a seven-year-old boy
column3: Michael Hammond
column4: and his 11-year-old sister Ann were convicted of stealing a loaf of bread and sentenced to hanging. Their public executions took place near the South Gates. The Member of Parliament at the time was Sir Robert Walpole
column5: generally regarded as the first Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.

column2: the town's decline was reversed by the somewhat late arrival of railway services in 1847
column3: provided mainly by the Great Eastern Railway
column4: subsequently the London and North Eastern Railway
column5: running to Hunstanton
column6: Dereham and Cambridge. The town was also served by the Midland and Great Northern Joint Railway (M&GN)
column7: which had offices at Austin Street
column8: and a station at South Lynn (now dismantled). This was also its operational control centre until relocation to Melton Constable. The former M&GN lines across Norfolk were closed to passengers in February 1959.

column1: The town's amenities continued to improve into the 20th century. A museum opened in 1904
column2: and a public library in 1905. The first cinema
column3: the Majestic
column4: was officially opened on 23 May 1928. (The year is commemorated in a stained glass window on the front of the building.) The town council began a programme of regeneration in the 1930s.

column2: King's Lynn was one of the first towns in Britain to suffer aerial bombing. On the night of 19 January 1915
column3: the town was bombed by a naval Zeppelin
column5: commanded by Captain Lieutenant Magnus von Platen-Hallermund. Eleven bombs were dropped
column6: both incendiary and high explosive
column7: doing extensive damage
column8: killing two people in Bentinck Street
column9: and injuring several others. When World War II began
column10: it was assumed that King's Lynn would be safe from bombing
column11: and many evacuees were sent from London but the town was not completely safe and suffered several raids.

column2: King's Lynn was designated an overflow town for London and its population increased. New estates were built at the Woottons and Gaywood. The town centre was redeveloped in the 1960s and many old buildings destroyed. Lynnsport
column3: a sports centre
column4: opened in 1982. The corn exchange was converted into a theatre in 1996.

column1: The local breweries had closed by the 1950s
column2: but new industries included food canning in the 1930s and soup-making in the 1950s. In the 1960s
column3: the council tried to encourage development by building an industrial estate at Hardwick. The new industries that arrived included light engineering
column4: clothing and chemicals and fishing remained important.

column2: work has been under way to regenerate the town under a multi-million-pound scheme. The 1960s Vancouver Shopping Centre (now the Vancouver Quarter) was refurbished in 2005 under the scheme
column3: but was expected to last only 25 years
column4: according to the construction firm
column5: even with a planned extension. An award-winning £6 million multi-storey car park was built.

column2: residential housing appeared on a large area of brownfield land. Plans for another housing estate alongside the River Nar were opposed by local people and halted by the economic situation. There is also a business park
column3: parkland
column4: a school
column5: shops and a new relief road in a £300 million plus scheme.

column2: King's Lynn became the United Kingdom's first member of The Hanse (Die Hanse)
column3: a network of towns and cities across Europe which historically belonged to the Hanseatic League. The league was an influential medieval trading association of merchant towns around the Baltic Sea and the North Sea
column4: which contributed to Lynn's development.

column1: The Borough Council commissioned and accepted a 2008 report by DTZ. It dubbed King's Lynn's workforce as "low-value" with a "low skills base" and the town as having a "poor lifestyle offer". The quality of services and amenities was "unattractive to higher-value inward investors and professional employees with higher disposable incomes". Average earnings were well below regional and national levels
column2: and many jobs in tourism
column3: leisure and hotels were subject to seasonal fluctuations and likewise poorly paid. Education and workforce qualifications were described as below the national average. The borough ranked 150th out of 354 for deprivation.In 2009
column4: a proposal was made for the Campbell's Meadow factory site to be redeveloped with a 5-hectare (12-acre) employment and business park. In June 2011 Tesco gained a permit for a superstore. On 8 June 2010
column5: it unveiled regeneration plans that would cost £32 million and were billed to create 900 jobs overall. Tesco pledged £4 million of improvements in other areas of the town. Whilst it planned to spend £1.6 million widening Hardwick Road
column6: the Sainsburys bid was preferred by the Council as offering the town more benefits.

column1: Sainsbury's £40 million plans for a superstore opposite Tesco on the Pinguin Foods site yielded an estimated 300 jobs. This was the key to securing the future of Pinguin Foods in King's Lynn. Pinguin Foods released 12 acres (5 ha) of its 44-acre (18 ha) site to accommodate the proposed store. Mortson Assets' and Sainsbury's plan included creating a link road between Scania Way and Queen Elizabeth Way to improve access and allow the industrial estate to expand and attract new employers
column2: while Sainsbury's maintains its store in the town centre. It has pledged £1.75 million for highways improvements and a further £7 million to invest in the Pinguin Foods factory.At 8 am on 15 January 2012
column3: the landmark Campbell's Tower was demolished – a competition winner
column4: Sarah Griffiths pulled the switch
column5: whose father
column6: Mick Locke
column7: had died aged 52 after being scalded by steam at the factory in 1995. It was Campbell's first UK factory when it opened in the 1950s. At its peak in the early 1990s it employed over 700.A fire station was opened by HM The Queen in February 2015.

column1: King's Lynn became a county borough in 1883. The present Borough of King's Lynn and West Norfolk was an amalgamation of the Borough of King's Lynn
column2: the urban districts of Downham Market and Hunstanton
column3: and the rural districts of Docking
column4: Downham
column5: Freebridge Lynn
column6: and Marshland.

column1: The shield in the coat of arms of King's Lynn and West Norfolk that of the ancient Borough of Lynn
column2: recorded at the College of Arms in 1563. It shows the legend of Margaret of Antioch
column3: who has appeared on Lynn shields since the 13th century
column4: and to whom the parish church is dedicated.

column1: The per chevron division and addition of a bordure serve to distinguish the shield from its predecessor
column2: while retaining its medieval simplicity. The bordure also suggests the wider bounds of the new authority
column3: with the seven parts symbolising the seven amalgamated authorities. The gull on the crest is a maritime reference. It has appeared as a supporter in some representations
column4: but officially stands on a bollard to make it distinctive. It supports a crown or coronet like a King's Lynn supporter and a lion from the crest of Downham Market.

column1: The coronet refers to the Borough's royal connections. The cross held by the gull is an extension of the two in the shield
column2: and the cross in the coat of arms of Freebridge Lynn Rural District.The supporters are based on the crest of the Hunstanton Urban District Council. The lion is a variation of the lions
column3: or leopards
column4: in the Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom and its fish tail suggests the borough's links with the sea.The fish–lion is also the centre feature in the borough's badge
column5: but here it is surrounded by a garland of oakleaves as a reference to the rural nature of much of the district. Oak leaves are also a feature of the coronet in the crest of the former Downham Market Urban District Council.

column1: King's Lynn is the northernmost settlement on the River Great Ouse
column2: lying 97 miles (156 km) north of London and 44 miles (71 km) west of Norwich. The town lies about 5 miles (8 km) south of the Wash
column3: a fourfold estuary subject to dangerous tides and shifting sandbanks
column4: on the north-west margin of East Anglia. King's Lynn has an area of 11 square miles (28 km2).

column1: The Great Ouse at Lynn is about 200 metres (660 ft) wide and the outfall for much of the Fens' drainage system. The much smaller Gaywood River also flows through the town
column2: joining the Great Ouse at the southern end of South Quay close to the town centre.

column1: A small part of the town
column2: known as West Lynn
column3: is on the west bank
column4: and linked to the town centre by one of the oldest ferries in the country. Other districts of King's Lynn include the town centre
column5: North Lynn
column6: South Lynn
column7: and Gaywood.

column1: King's Lynn has a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb). The annual mean daytime temperature is approximately 14 °C (57 °F). January is the coldest month with mean minimum temperatures between 0 to 1 °C (32.0 to 33.8 °F). July and August are the warmest months
column2: with mean daily maximum temperatures of approximately 21 °C (70 °F).There are two Met Office weather stations close to King's Lynn: Terrington St Clement
column3: about 4 miles (6 km) to the west and RAF Marham
column4: about 10 miles (16 km) to the south east.

column1: The absolute maximum temperature at Terrington stands at 35.1 °C (95.2 °F) recorded in August 2003
column2: though in a more average year the warmest day will only reach 29.4 °C (84.9 °F)
column3: with 13.8 days in total attaining a temperature of 25.1 °C (77.2 °F) or more. Typically all these figures are marginally cooler than the southern half of the Fens due to the common presence of an onshore sea breeze
column4: and occasional haar (cold sea fog)
column5: particularly in early summer and late spring. However
column6: with a strong enough offshore breeze
column7: the area can be notably warm. Terrington (along with Cambridge Botanical Gardens) achieved the national highest temperature of 2007
column9: set in January 1979. A total of 41.6 nights will report an air frost at Terrington and 51.9 nights at Marham.

column1: Annual rainfall totals 621 mm (24 in) at Marham
column2: and 599 mm (24 in) at Terrington
column3: with 1 mm or more falling on 115 and 113 days
column4: respectively. All averages refer to the 30-year observation period 1971–2000.

column1: The largest of the town's several public parks are the Walks
column2: a historic 17-hectare urban park in the centre of King's Lynn. The Walks are the only town walk in Norfolk to survive from the 18th century. The Heritage Lottery Fund donated £4.3 million towards their restoration
column3: including the addition of modern amenities. They also include the Red Mount
column4: a Grade II-listed 15th-century chapel. In 1998
column5: the Walks were designated by English Heritage as a Grade II National historic park.

column1: The Walks as a whole had a different and earlier origin
column2: in that they were conceived not as a municipal park
column3: as one understands the term today
column4: but as a promenade for the citizens
column5: away from the smell
column6: grime and bustle of the town centre. Harding's Pits form another public park
column7: to the south of the town. This informal area of open space with large public sculptures was laid out to reflect the history of the town. Harding's Pits are managed by local volunteers under a management firm
column8: which has successfully fought off the Borough Council's attempts to turn them into an attenuation drain.

column4: King's Lynn
column5: together with West Norfolk
column6: had a population of 143
column8: with an average population density of 1.0 persons per hectare. For figures after 2011 see King's Lynn and West Norfolk.

column1: King's Lynn has always been a centre for fishing and seafood (especially inshore prawns
column2: shrimps and cockles). There have also been glass-making and small-scale engineering works (many fairground and steam engines were built here). It still contains much agricultural-related industry
column3: including food processing. There are a number of chemical factories and the town retains a role as an import centre. In general
column4: it is a regional centre for a still sparsely populated part of England.

column1: King's Lynn was the fastest growing port in Great Britain in 2008. Department for Transport figures show that through-put increased by 33 per cent.In 2008
column2: the German Palm Group began to erect one of the world's largest paper machines. This was constructed by Voith Paper. With a web speed of up to 2000 metres a minute and a web width of 10.63 metres
column3: it can produce 400
column4: 000 metres a year of newsprint paper. The production is based on 100-per-cent recycled paper. The start-up was on 21 August 2009.

column1: The Port of King's Lynn has facilities for dry bulk cargo such as cereals and liquid bulk products such as petroleum products for Pace Petroleum. It also handles timber imported from Scandinavia and the Baltics and has large handling sheds for steel imports.
King's Lynn is the primary retail centre in West Norfolk
column2: also for people living outside the border of West Norfolk. The town centre is dominated by budget shops
column3: reflecting the spending power of much of the population. The town centre fulfils a leisure role with entertainment centres
column4: bars and restaurants
column5: and has a range of service functions. There are around 5
column6: 300 retailing jobs.The town centre has 73
column7: 000 sq.m. of retail floor space in 347 shops
column8: which exceeds the comparable centres of Bury St Edmunds and Boston. However
column9: whilst the percentage of floor space in comparison shopping and that occupied by multiple retailers is above the national average
column10: King's Lynn offers limited range of choice.

column1: Tourism in King's Lynn is a minor industry
column2: but attracts visitors to its historic centre. It acts as a base for visiting the Queen's home at Sandringham and other great country houses in the area. Within the town and across the nearby Fenland are some of the finest historic churches in Britain
column3: built in a period when King's Lynn and its hinterland were very wealthy from trade and wool.

column1: The town is connected to the local cities of Norwich and Peterborough via the A47 and to Cambridge via the A10. It is also linked to Spalding and the North via the A17 and to other parts of Norfolk by the A148 and the A149

A £7 million programme to redevelop the infrastructure of the town centre in the 2010s was largely provided by the Community Infrastructure Fund. The department programme is a collection of smaller developments
column2: which are detailed below.Work on a cycle and bus route between the town centre and South Lynn began in June 2010 at a cost of £850
column3: 000. It runs 720 metres long
column4: running from Morston Drift to Millfleet
column5: with buses travelling in both directions and features a separate path for pedestrians and bicycles
column6: which coincides with the bus route when crossing the Nar sluice. As part of the development
column7: the Millfleet–St James' Road junction is being developed.A contraflow lane for bicycles was proposed
column8: but not built along Norfolk Street from Albert Street to Blackfriars Road. This would have included a development of the Norfolk Road–Railway Road junction to better accommodate buses and bicycles. Similar work was to have taken place at the Norfolk Street–Littleport Street junction
column9: so that buses would not get caught in the town-centre gyratory system.Bus priority measures have been added to four sets of traffic lights along St James' Road. This gives buses quicker access to the town centre and normalise journey times.Southgates Roundabout has been redeveloped. Many of its approach roads have been widened in the run up to the junction and the road markings redone in an attempt to improve lane discipline. Southgates Roundabout is a noted congestion hot spot.Other small developments are taking place to make junctions more car-friendly.

column2: the terminus of the Fen Line
column3: is the only rail facility in King's Lynn. It provides services to Cambridge and London King's Cross. South Lynn railway station closed to passengers in 1959

column1: West Norfolk Council are still ostensibly considering reopening a railway route between the King's Lynn railway station and the Hunstanton railway station. The possibility was proposed at a meeting of the council's Regeneration and Environment Panel on 29 October 2008. This had last been discussed in the 1990s. An environmental case was made for reviving the line to relieve road congestion.
Nearly all Stagecoach services in the area have been withdrawn

column1: The Guild of St George was founded in 1376 and in 1406 acquired land for the Guildhall
column2: which was in use by 1428. The Guild performed plays in the Guildhall
column3: the first known production being a nativity play in January 1445. This makes it the UK's oldest working theatre.

column1: The Guildhall was used for meetings
column2: dinners and performance until in 1547
column3: when King Edward VI dissolved the Guilds. It then became the property of Lynn Corporation and known as the Common Town Hall. Research by the University of East Anglia confirms as probable the oral history of Kings Lynn that William Shakespeare performed in the Guildhall in 1593. This is the only still-working theatre in the world that can credibly claim to have hosted Shakespeare. In 1766 Guildhall shows were so popular that a new interior was built inside the present structure
column4: probably on the earlier footprint. By 1945 the Guildhall was almost derelict and in danger of demolition. It was bought by Alexander Penrose
column5: who gave it to the National Trust in 1951. The Pilgrim Trust
column6: Arts Council and public subscription led to the Guildhall's conversion into an Arts Centre. Queen Elizabeth (the Queen Mother) opened the venue in July 1951 and launched the King's Lynn Festival.

column1: Today the Guildhall is owned by the National Trust
column2: leased by the Borough Council of King's Lynn and West Norfolk. Various groups are involved with the use of the building including Shakespeare's Guildhall Trust
column3: King's Lynn Festival
column4: King's Lynn Community Cinema Club
